      • intersection

        public static float intersection(int[] histA,
                                 int orientationA,
                                 int[] histB,
                                 int orientationB)
        CAVEAT: small amount of testing done, not yet throughly tested. calculate the intersection of histA and histB which have already been normalized to the same scale. A result of 0 is maximally dissimilar and a result of 1 is maximally similar. The orientations are needed to compare the correct rotated bins to one another. Internally, orientation of 90 leads to no shift for rotation, and orientation near 0 results in rotation of nBins/2, etc... Note that an orientation of 90 is a unit vector from x,y=0,0 to x,y=0,1. Note also that you may want to try the rotation of oppossite direction.
        Parameters:
        histA -
        orientationA -
        histB -
        orientationB -
        Returns:

      • intersection

        public static float intersection(int[] histA,

        calculate the intersection of histA and histB which have already been normalized to the same scale. A result of 0 is maximally dissimilar and a result of 1 is maximally similar. The orientations are needed to compare the correct rotated bins to one another. Internally, orientation of 90 leads to no shift for rotation, and orientation near 0 results in rotation of nBins/2, etc... Note that an orientation of 90 is a unit vector from x,y=0,0 to x,y=0,1.
        Parameters:
        histA -
        histB -
        Returns:

      • diff

        public static float[] diff(int[] histA,
                           int orientationA,
                           int[] histB,
                           int orientationB)
        CAVEAT: small amount of testing done, not yet throughly tested. calculate the difference of histA and histB (normalized by the maximum value in their histograms). A result of 0 is maximally similar and a result of 1 is maximally dissimilar. The orientations are needed to compare the correct rotated bins to one another. Internally, orientation of 90 leads to no shift for rotation, and orientation near 0 results in rotation of nBins/2, etc... Note that an orientation of 90 is a unit vector from x,y=0,0 to x,y=0,1.
        Parameters:
        histA -
        orientationA -
        histB -
        orientationB -
        Returns:
        difference, error

A result of 0 is maximally similar and a result of 1 is maximally dissimilar. The orientations are needed to compare the correct rotated bins to one another. Internally, orientation of 90 leads to no shift for rotation, and orientation near 0 results in rotation of nBins/2, etc... Note that an orientation of 90 is a unit vector from x,y=0,0 to x,y=0,1.

      • extractWindow

        public static void extractWindow(int[][] histograms,
                                 int startX,
                                 int stopX,
                                 int startY,
                                 int stopY,
                                 int w,
                                 int h,
                                 int[] output,
                                 int[] outputN)
        runtime complexity is O(nBins)
        Parameters:
        histograms - the 2D histogram integral image. the first dimension is the pixel index and the 2nd is the histogram bin, e.g. histograms[pixIdx][binIdx].
        startX -
        stopX - the last x pixel in the window, inclusive
        startY -
        stopY - the last y pixel in the window, inclusive
        w - image width
        h - image height
        output -
        outputN - an empty 1 dimensional array of size 1 to return the number of pixels in the cell

      • extractWindow

        public static void extractWindow(int[][] histograms,
                                 int startX,
                                 int stopX,
                                 int startY,
                                 int stopY,
                                 int w,
                                 int h,
                                 long[] output,
                                 int[] outputN)
        extract the sum of histograms in the window inclusively defined as (startX:stopX, startY:stopY). runtime complexity is O(nBins)
        Parameters:
        histograms - the 2D histogram integral image. the first dimension is the pixel index and the 2nd is the histogram bin, e.g. histograms[pixIdx][binIdx].
        startX -
        stopX - the last x pixel in the window, inclusive
        startY -
        stopY - the last y pixel in the window, inclusive
        output -
        outputN - an empty 1 dimensional array of size 1 to return the number of pixels in the cell

      • applyWindowedSum

        public static void applyWindowedSum(int[][] histograms,
                                    int w,
                                    int h,
                                    int N_PIX_PER_CELL_DIM)
        apply a windowed sum across the 2D integral histogram image, where the window size is N_PIX_PER_CELL_DIM. The result is an image of histograms, where each histogram represents the integration over the surrounding N_PIX_PER_CELL_DIM window. For windows near the image edge, a factor is applied to bring the counts up by factor (N_PIX_PER_CELL_DIM/n_pix_in_window). The 2D histograms array is then made into a 2D integral histogram image again.
        Parameters:
        histograms - the 2D histogram integral image. the first dimension is the pixel index and the 2nd is the histogram bin, e.g. histograms[pixIdx][binIdx]
        w -
        h -
        N_PIX_PER_CELL_DIM -

      • applyWindowedSum0

        static int[][] applyWindowedSum0(int[][] histograms,
                                 int w,
                                 int h,
                                 int N_PIX_PER_CELL_DIM)
        apply a windowed sum across the gradient integral histogram image, where the window size is N_PIX_PER_CELL_DIM. The result is an image of histograms, where each histogram represents the integration over the surrounding N_PIX_PER_CELL_DIM window. The result is NOT a 2D integral histogram image, just a 2D histogram image;
        Parameters:
        histograms - the 2D histogram integral image. the first dimension is the pixel index and the 2nd is the histogram bin, e.g. histograms[pixIdx][binIdx]
        w -
        h -
        N_PIX_PER_CELL_DIM -
        Returns:
        the 2D histogram image smoothed over a window of N_PIX_PER_CELL_DIM size. Note that this is not an integral image.

      • transformIntoIntegral2DHist

        public static int[][] transformIntoIntegral2DHist(int[][] hist,
                                                  int imageWidth,
                                                  int imageHeight)
        Parameters:
        hist - a 2D histogram image of format hist[pixIdx][hitBinIdx].
        imageWidth -
        imageHeight -
        Returns:
        a 2D histogram integral image of format hist[pixIdx][hitBinIdx].
